comment.author: 35687899@N00
comment._content: 293 Bowery @ Houston, looking north along the short block to E. 1st Street. There's some kind of garden and a glassed-in apartment building called the Avalon there now (Google Street View). A little more about the buildings on the right: "Between 1884 and 1932, the Bowery YMCA, housed for a time at Wesley Hall (291-293 Bowery), also provided mission-style services and housing. Today the building houses a Tibetan Buddhist meditation and teaching center. McGurk’s Suicide Hall at 295 Bowery also became a rescue mission for a time during the early 20th century." www.placeinhistory.org/projects/bowery/?page=10 50 years earlier (1863), the same spot was the location of a huge hotel fire covered in the NY Times. The building next door (295 Bowery) was a tobacco warehouse heavily damaged by water during the fighting of the fire.

comment.author: 16533831@N03
comment._content: I like the el tracks in the upper left-hand corner. I'll use this shot in a lesson for my 8th graders in our New York City Unit.

comment.author: 35687899@N00
comment._content: Yes, the elevated tracks you can see in this pic were narrow because they were one-way -- the uptown el ran on one side of the street above one sidewalk and the downtown el on the other side of the street above the other sidewalk. Bowery is a wide street and had several parallel streetcar lines on the street in between the two el trestles, as seen here. The Bowery el was built in 1878 and torn down in 1955. McGuirk's Suicide Hall, at the location of the "RESTAURANT" seen in this pic, was a notorious theater/saloon sort of establishment that supposedly acquired its nickname because so many young women committed suicide there. Some of these buildings actually lasted until 2005 when they were torn down for the Avalon. Next block up is where CBGB's used to be.

comment.author: 29079609@N02
comment._content: it merited a small article in Time Magazine in 1926 for making men get up and out at 5 AM! www.time.com/time/magazine/article/0,9171,728797,00.html as noted on the sign, doors opened at 7pm.

comment.author: 91829349@N00
comment._content:
The Hadley Hall was originally the "Volksgarten."  Per nysonglines.com : 

 "In the 19th Century, a gathering place for the German-American community that once dominated this neighborhood. Later Wesley Hall, a notable Bowery mission, which was renamed Hadley Hall after Samuel Hadley, the Civil War vet who ran the mission for many years. A venue for labor meetings. For the past 40 years it has housed Stanton Trading, a restaurant supply company. It too was demolished in 2005--respresenting a failure of the Landmark Commission to preserve New York's historic buildings. "

comment.author: 70251312@N00
comment._content: The New York Times in January, 1914 (the date of this photograph), ran a letter from J. G. Hallimond, Superintendent of the Bowery Mission, explaining the need for breadlines to assuage hunger in the ranks of honest unemployed men: January 21, 1914: query.nytimes.com/mem/archive-free/pdf?res=9B06EFD81F3BE6...
